Computing the z-score of a list of numbers
```{r}
x_vec = rnorm(25, mean = 7, sd = 4)

(x_vec - mean(x_vec)) / sd(x_vec)
```

Same example, but with iteration
```{r}
z_scores = function(x) {
  
  if (!is.numeric(x)) {
    stop("Argument x should be numeric")
  } else if (length(x) < 3) {
    stop("Z scores cannot be computed for vectors with length less than 3")
  }
  
  z = mean(x) / sd(x)
  
  z
}

z_scores(x = x_vec)
z_scores(x = 1:10)
z_scores(x = rbinom(1000, 1, .6))
```


Multiple outputs - means and sd from the vector output & return a list
```{r}
mean_and_sd = function(x) {
  
  if (!is.numeric(x)) {
    stop("Argument x should be numeric")
  } else if (length(x) == 1) {
    stop("Cannot be computed for length 1 vectors")
  }
  
  mean_x = mean(x)
  sd_x = sd(x)

  list(mean = mean_x, 
       sd = sd_x)
}
```

same but return multiple values in a data frame
```{r}
mean_and_sd = function(x) {
  
  if (!is.numeric(x)) {
    stop("Argument x should be numeric")
  } else if (length(x) == 1) {
    stop("Cannot be computed for length 1 vectors")
  }
  
  mean_x = mean(x)
  sd_x = sd(x)

  tibble(
    mean = mean_x, 
    sd = sd_x
  )
}

mean_and_sd(x = x_vec)
mean_and_sd(x = 1:10)
mean_and_sd(x = rbinom(1000, 1, .6))
```

Simulations - multiple inputs and outputs
```{r}
sim_mean_sd = function(n_obs, true_mean = 7, true_sd = 4) {
  
  sim_data = tibble(
    x = rnorm(n_obs, mean = true_mean, sd = true_sd),
  )
  
  sim_data %>% 
    summarize(
      mu_hat = mean(x),
      sigma_hat = sd(x)
    )
}

sim_mean_sd(n_obs = 25, true_mean = 100, true_sd = 1)
```


revisiting past examples - scraping amazon
```{r}
url = "https://www.amazon.com/product-reviews/B00005JNBQ/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_viewopt_rvwer?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=avp_only_reviews&sortBy=recent&pageNumber=1"

dynamite_html = read_html(url)

review_titles = 
  dynamite_html %>%
  html_nodes(".a-text-bold span") %>%
  html_text()

review_stars = 
  dynamite_html %>%
  html_nodes("#cm_cr-review_list .review-rating") %>%
  html_text() %>%
  str_extract("^\\d") %>%
  as.numeric()

review_text = 
  dynamite_html %>%
  html_nodes(".review-text-content span") %>%
  html_text() %>% 
  str_replace_all("\n", "") %>% 
  str_trim()

reviews = tibble(
  title = review_titles,
  stars = review_stars,
  text = review_text
)
```

write a function to get reviews
```{r}
read_page_reviews <- function(url) {
  
      html = read_html(url)
      
      review_titles = 
        html %>%
        html_nodes(".a-text-bold span") %>%
        html_text()
      
      review_stars = 
        html %>%
        html_nodes("#cm_cr-review_list .review-rating") %>%
        html_text() %>%
        str_extract("^\\d") %>%
        as.numeric()
      
      review_text = 
        html %>%
        html_nodes(".review-text-content span") %>%
        html_text() %>% 
        str_replace_all("\n", "") %>% 
        str_trim() %>% 
        str_subset("The media could not be loaded.", negate = TRUE) %>% 
        str_subset("^$", negate = TRUE)
      
      tibble(
        title = review_titles,
        stars = review_stars,
        text = review_text
      )
      
  reviews
}
```

testing that above works for single urls
```{r}
url = "https://www.amazon.com/product-reviews/B00005JNBQ/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_viewopt_rvwer?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=avp_only_reviews&sortBy=recent&pageNumber=3"

read_page_reviews(url)
```

LOTR data - original code
```{r}
fellowship_ring = readxl::read_excel("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", range = "B3:D6") %>%
  mutate(movie = "fellowship_ring")

two_towers = readxl::read_excel("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", range = "F3:H6") %>%
  mutate(movie = "two_towers")

return_king = readxl::read_excel("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", range = "J3:L6") %>%
  mutate(movie = "return_king")

lotr_tidy = bind_rows(fellowship_ring, two_towers, return_king) %>%
  janitor::clean_names() %>%
  gather(key = sex, value = words, female:male) %>%
  mutate(race = str_to_lower(race)) %>% 
  select(movie, everything())
```

LOTR data - iteration of above code
```{r}
lotr_load_and_tidy = function(path, range, movie_name) {
  
  df = readxl::read_excel(path, range = range) %>%
    janitor::clean_names() %>%
    gather(key = sex, value = words, female:male) %>%
    mutate(race = str_to_lower(race),
           movie = movie_name)
  
  df
  
}

lotr_tidy = 
  bind_rows(
    lotr_load_and_tidy("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", "B3:D6", "fellowship_ring"),
    lotr_load_and_tidy("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", "F3:H6", "two_towers"),
    lotr_load_and_tidy("./LotR_Words_copy.xlsx", "J3:L6", "return_king")) %>%
  select(movie, everything())
```


Functions as arguments
```{r}
x_vec = rnorm(25, 0, 1)

my_summary = function(x, summ_func) {
  summ_func(x)
}

my_summary(x_vec, sd)

my_summary(x_vec, IQR)

my_summary(x_vec, var)
```

Scoping and names:
Examples like this are tricky, but emphasize an issue that comes up a lot in writing functions: you define a variable in your global environment and use it in your function, but it isnâ€™t passed as an argument. This is easy to miss, especially when you go from code written in chunks to a function, and can be hard to track down if you empty your working directory or change a variable name. The best advice I have is to give your arguments useful names and think carefully about where everything is defined, and to periodically restart R and try everything again!


```{r}
f = function(x) {
  z = x + y
  z
}

x = 1
y = 2

f(x = y)
```
